themes.title: The Importance of Green in Chinese Art
points: Green was a favorite color at the imperial court in Beijing, symbolizing wealth and elegance.
Look at the porcelain artifact with a white-green glaze from the Southern Song dynasty. Imagine how the soft green might represent nature or calmness.
Ask students: What feelings or images come to mind when you see the color green? Relate this to their own cultures.

themes.title: Techniques and Materials in Chinese Porcelain
points: Porcelain is a type of ceramic made from fine clay, fired at high temperatures to create a smooth, glass-like surface.
The Southern Song dynasty artifact shows the skill of creating delicate white-green glazes. Compare this to painting techniques in art class.
Use visual metaphor: Porcelain is like a blank canvas, and the glaze is the artist's brushstroke.

themes.title: Mythical and Animal Imagery in Chinese Art
points: Many Chinese artworks feature mythical creatures or animals, often symbolizing power, protection, or wisdom.
Ask students to imagine what kind of mythical creature might live in the green landscapes shown in the glaze colors.
Relate to their interests: If you were designing a plate, what animal or mythical creature would you include? Why?

themes.title: The Wucai Palette: A Burst of Color
points: Wucai means 'five colors' in Chinese, and this palette includes red, green, brown, and yellow overglaze enamels.
Point out the plates painted in wucai colors and discuss how the vibrant mix creates energy and movement.
Ask students: How do the colors work together? Which color stands out most to you?

themes.title: Connecting Art and Language
points: Art is like a storyâ€”each color, shape, and symbol tells us something about the culture and time period.
Encourage students to describe the artwork using simple English words like 'soft,' 'bright,' 'smooth,' or 'calm.'
Ask students to write a short description of their favorite piece in the exhibit, focusing on colors and shapes.
